All our machines returned safely. ranean.On the 7th July the monitors " Earl of Peterborough " and ': Sir Thomas Picton " assisted an Italian force in bombarding enemy works at M^la, with successful results. In this operation British aircraft also co-operated, spotting for the monitors. Further, two machines from Taranto bombed the aerodrome at Tirana, and six from Otranto, working in pairs, attacked Kuchi Bridge on several occasions, the bridge being reported completely destroyed. One enemy machine was driven down and one of our machines was brought down, but was destroyed by the pilot, who, with the observer, was taken prisoner but afterwards rescued.On 9th July one of our Coastal Motor Boats was lost by fire whilst exercising at Casualties Spithead. One of the crew was burnt severely, but the others escaped injury.ATTACK UPON ENEMY SUBMARINES.During the week under review it is estimated that from 16 to 21 large enemy sub- Submarines marines were operating, included in this number being three " cruisers," one possibly of a operating, new type. Of the latter, one is homeward bound and the other two are operating on Atlantic routes while apparently on their way to American waters. Most of the remaining large boats have either been working between the south of Ireland and the north of Spain, or have been on passage, but the enemy recommenced operating on'a small scale off the coasts of the Bay of Biscay.The only area in Home Waters where activity has been intense has been the Yorkshire coast.(C 1292) Wt.50' IIIS H & Actions The following Table shows the number of actions between Allied craft and enemywith enemy submarines which are reported to have taken place in all waters during recent weeks, 1 "m 1 ' and the nature of the craft which have been engaged ; and also the number of submarines which have been destroyed as the result of such actions : Week ended Week ended Week ended Week ended June 22nd. (on which port most of the enemy's minelaying submarines have been based) at which such mines were located.It will be seen that not only has the number of mines laid tended to decrease during the period, but that the tendency for them to be laid nearer and nearer to Zeebrugge is still more marked during the last three months. If the number of minelaying sub-marines available had remained constant, and it had been a definite policy on the part of the enemy to lay mines nearer to the Flanders bases, the number of mines laid should have increased owing to the greater number of trips that could have been made. It may therefore fairly be inferred that the reduction in enemy minelaying activity is principally due to a great diminution in the number of submarines which are available for minelaying, although it is doubtless also partly accounted for by the fact that the utility of Zeebrugge ' . as a base has been much restricted.Minelaying. So far as is known no enemy mines have been laid in Home Waters during the week under review, and only two enemy moored mines have been swept up, one of these being accounted for by British minesweepers off Cherbourg. This is the first week for over two years in which no minelaying activity on the part of the enemy has been observed. No enemy ships have entered or left men. Rotterdam.FOREIGN NAVAL INTELLIGENCE. Russia.The local Soviet at Archangel is reported to be at present in a conciliatory mood, but plainly intimates its decision to be guided by Moscow alone, and Rear-Admiral Kemp is of opinion that the occupation of Archangel by the Allies will be opposed. The situation as regards food has become so acute that orders have been given to discharge s.s. " Egba," whose cargo is to be handed over to the local co-operative society for distribution in Archangel.In the Murmansk district H.M.S. " Attentive " made a successful reconnaissance to Soroka on 7th July. The landing party was well received by the local inhabitants,, who reported that the Bolsheviks had retired in a southerly direction. The railway had been damaged both north and south of Soroka, but it was hoped to be able to repair the section between Soroka and Kem without great difficulty.The situation in Vladivostok is now satisfactory, the control of the town having been taken over by Allied landing parties.Russian small craft at Yeisk are still causing the enemy anxiety in the Sea of Azov.A French source reports that two Russian destroyers arrived at Sevastopol on 25th June. On 6th July the Turks occupied Tuapse, but no further news has been received of the destroyer " Derski," which arrived there on 18th June from Novorossisk. The destroyer " Kertch," however, has been sunk off Tuapse by her own crew.Portugal.The majority of the trawlers employed on the Portuguese Coastal Patrol have been withdrawn from service, in order that they may be utilized for adding to the food supply . of the country.Spain.An important decree has been recently promulgated, introducing extensive reforms into the Spanish Navy. The present establishment of officers of all ranks is much in excess of requirements, and measures are being taken to reduce it by granting higher pensions and a step in rank to officers who retire, and by limiting promotion to one-half of the vacancies caused by retirements. The age limit for compulsory retirement, however, still remains very high as compared with the British Navy.Japan.On 12th July the Japanese battleship " Kawachi" was destroyed as the result of an internal explosion, about 600 lives being lost.Naval Staff,mh July, 1918.[Appendices.The following Table shows the number of enemy mines destroyed and British vessels Casualties, sunk: by mine in Home Waters (including the Havre and Cherbourg areas) in recent weeks : APPENDIX I.Statement of Numbers and Tonnage of SAILINGS and LOSSES of British and Foreign Merchant Steamships of over 500 tons grossfor the Week ended j3th July, 1918.
